message_1:
One precise numerical problem for a math student to solve in Second-order logic could be:

Let Q be the set of all rational numbers. Using second-order logic, construct a statement that defines a subset of Q that contains only irrational numbers.
message_2:
It is not possible to construct a subset of Q that contains only irrational numbers, as Q is the set of all rational numbers by definition. Irrational numbers are not part of the set Q. Instead, you can define a set I of all irrational numbers using second-order logic.

Let I be the set of all irrational numbers. Using second-order logic, we can define I as follows:

∀x (x ∈ I ↔ ¬(∃p, q ∈ ℤ (q ≠ 0 ∧ x = p/q)))

This statement says that for all x, x is an element of I if and only if there do not exist integers p and q such that q is not equal to 0 and x is equal to the fraction p/q. This definition captures the essence of irrational numbers, which cannot be expressed as a ratio of two integers.
